channel.title: Wardriving
channel.description:
Anyone here do it? I'm posting here because I've yet to hear of anyone doing anything like this in Windows.
I don't have a GPS so I don't drive around and plot networks or anything, but anywhere I go and I have my laptop I always use Kismet or airodump-ng to look at networks. I do it every so often at home at different times to see if any wireless networks change or what times of the day they're being used most.
Also, not so related to wardriving, but I've successfully cracked passwords for just about all of my friend's and neighbor's wireless networks, and then showed it to them. Then I tell them the importance of something like WPA2 and a strong password. Not to mention that having something like that open in a public place is DEFINITELY a conversation starter, almost to the point where I alt+tab to it quickly to check up because most people are like wtf.

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:33, topic:373736”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=469739.msg3438512#msg3438512 date=1292947721]

@Mopar, I agree, I’m pretty sure it’s just all the ports but that. So SSH tunneling from my port 80 to my home @ port whatever should work.

But you have your source and destination ports mixed up. Your sshd would have to run on port 80 at your house, like a web browser (your destination port), your source port would be anything in the range 1000-65535, you don’t need to be concerned with it, it’s basically random.

Also, I noticed you talked about downloading torrents with this, that wouldn’t help you because you will be limited by the speed of your home connection, so you might as well just physically download them on your home machine. Look into something like transmission-daemon for this.
[/quote]

Now I’m confused. How would my data get out from my laptop from a port that’s not 80 if they’re blocking all the ports but 80?[/quote]

Basically what Mopman said. They block all destination ports but 80, they couldn’t care less about the origin ports, as I said, they are for all intents and purposes random anyway. All you need to worry about is you need to run your ssh server on port 80 at your house, then connect to it from school.

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @Mopman Mopman
item.description:
@Mopman wrote:

because they don’t block origin ports, they block traffic thats outbound to a port that isnt 80

when you connect to a webserver, it doesnt originate from 80 on your machien either

Read full topic

@Mopar, I agree, I’m pretty sure it’s just all the ports but that. So SSH tunneling from my port 80 to my home @ port whatever should work.

But you have your source and destination ports mixed up. Your sshd would have to run on port 80 at your house, like a web browser (your destination port), your source port would be anything in the range 1000-65535, you don’t need to be concerned with it, it’s basically random.

Also, I noticed you talked about downloading torrents with this, that wouldn’t help you because you will be limited by the speed of your home connection, so you might as well just physically download them on your home machine. Look into something like transmission-daemon for this.[/quote]

Now I’m confused. How would my data get out from my laptop from a port that’s not 80 if they’re blocking all the ports but 80?

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

SomethingToHide:

@Mopar, I agree, I’m pretty sure it’s just all the ports but that. So SSH tunneling from my port 80 to my home @ port whatever should work.

But you have your source and destination ports mixed up. Your sshd would have to run on port 80 at your house, like a web browser (your destination port), your source port would be anything in the range 1000-65535, you don’t need to be concerned with it, it’s basically random.

Also, I noticed you talked about downloading torrents with this, that wouldn’t help you because you will be limited by the speed of your home connection, so you might as well just physically download them on your home machine. Look into something like transmission-daemon for this.

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“la­wl, post:24, topic:373736”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=469739.msg3438136#msg3438136 date=1292909330]

i use mac filtering at home, cause encryption means no 1080p video streaming

That’s what a wire is for.
[/quote]
yeah but say i want to stream video from my wireless desktop (would be a bitch to wire into that room) to my htpc[/quote]

Yea, my wife isn’t too happy about the 100ft bright yellow cat5 strung from the 1Gbit switch upstairs all the way down to the PS3 either, but she deals with it, and after I watch all my 1080p movies I unhook it, because 720p and less streams fine over wireless N with WPA2.

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

7SMkI.png1208×727

Hah, apparently not. It is quite blatantly obvious that it’s an outgoing SSH connection from the first few packets.

Now, how to patch the software to masquerade itself as HTTPS…

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Moparisthebest:

You meant they block everything but HTTP, not HTML

LOL. I’m very tired right now -_-

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

I don’t believe they would be able to tell the difference between HTTPS and SSH, even if there happens to be a sophisticated way to do it, I doubt your university goes that far.

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @Unhandled Unhandled
item.description:
@Unhandled wrote:

Yes there will be a bit of a speed hit, but if your net and the proxy’s net is fast it shouldn’t be noticeable.

If they really are blocking everything, you’ll have to set up your ssh tunnel on port 80 (or if HTTPS works you could use 443).

HTTPS and SSH both use SSL, correct? Does this make it impossible to distinguish between the two, since you can’t look at the actual data due to it being encrypted? Or do they use some crappy unencrypted headers for establishing connections that allows packet inspection software to block one or the other?

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“SomethingToHide, post:15, topic:373736”]Does internet speed take a hit?

This might prove useful. At my college this quarter they seem to have blocked all ports but HTML, probably to stop all the kids from playing MMOs in class.

Either way, I can’t check my mail or anything besides browse the internet basically. I don’t usually do much other than check my mail, but it’d be cool if I could route all my traffic through an encrypted tunnel so I could also download TV shows via BT also.[/quote]

Your computer has to encrypt and decrypt the packets, but honestly it doesn’t slow it down that much.

You meant they block everything but HTTP, not HTML But I’d say you could host ssh on port 80 someplace and do this just fine.

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @SomethingToHide STH
item.description:
@SomethingToHide wrote:

Does internet speed take a hit?

This might prove useful. At my college this quarter they seem to have blocked all ports but HTML, probably to stop all the kids from playing MMOs in class.

Either way, I can’t check my mail or anything besides browse the internet basically. I don’t usually do much other than check my mail, but it’d be cool if I could route all my traffic through an encrypted tunnel so I could also download TV shows via BT also.

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Mopman:

The easiest thing to do is not do anything secure over wireless, because it’s not secure. But perhaps I’m just old fashioned paranoid.

Or when you do something ‘secure’, just set up a SOCKS proxy over ssh and route all your traffic through that. When I used the university’s wifi quite a bit, I actually had a script set up so that on login it would set up the proxy and force all my programs to route through it, then everything you do is encrypted so well that probably the NSA is the only organization that could crack it.

http://wiki.freaks-unidos.net/weblogs/azul/firefox-ssh-tunnel

Read full topic

item.title: Wardriving
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

MAC filtering isn’t any good either, because if a person is tech-savvy enough to crack your encryption password, then they are plenty capable of cloning a MAC address, that’s easy stuff.

I’ve never cracked any wireless passwords though, because I’ve never had a card capable of doing so, of course I haven’t looked at the options for a few years, so maybe someone has came out with a new driver for my card…

Read full topic
